Award.AwardTitle: A Miniature Archival Tag for Long Range Fish Tracking in the Ocean
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tagging of aquatic animals is used to reveal movement patterns, home range, habitat preferences, gender differences, distribution patterns, etc. and represents a methodology that has been employed for many years. With previous NSF funding the PI developed a miniaturized RAFOS receiver on a microchip designed to study the movements of (small) fishes such as salmon, flounder and Atlantic cod. The prototype was completed. This proposal requests funding to complete the fish-tag assembly (the design work for which is done), and build 100 plus devices for a field test tracking yellowtail flounder in the Nantucket Lightship Protected Area. They plan to improve the performance of the signal detection system by improving the time keeping by correcting for the temperature dependence of the crystal oscillator and lengthen the signal correlator to improve the signal detection capability at extended distances.

Broader Impacts:

The Broader Impacts were excellent, stemming primarily from the potential application arising from the miniaturization. The long-term impact is likely to be much more general than fish tagging. Oceanographers can use fish as sensor platforms and ecologist can use information about migration and the physical environment to enhance understanding of fish migration. The new technology may thus become important for interdisciplinary research and stimulate scientific cooperation among fields. This is fundamental for understanding and quantification of biophysical interactions which is a prerequisite for ecosystem understanding and modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this research project was to build an archival tag capable of recording the position of small fishes in the Ocean as well as collecting environmental data such as temperature and water pressure. The starting point for this work was an existing custom microchip, called fish-chip, which was developed with the help of a previous NSF award.

The fish-chip is responsible for all essential operations of the tag. This includes the acoustic arrival time detection, all control and interface functions, sensing temperature, pressure and battery voltage as well as  digitizing and reformatting all data for subsequent storage in separate nonvolatile memory chips. Figure 1 shows a picture of the redesigned final fish-tag die while figure 2 reveals the small physical size of the packaged die.

The underwater positioning system works on the same principle as a GPS receiver. It records the arrival time of signals (in this case pressure or sound waves) generated periodically by remote sources (sound sources in our case) located at precisely know geographic locations. The major challenge in this endeavor has been to design an acoustic receiver that operates with a power budget of not more than 50-75 uW, in other words, a million times less than the power consumed by a typical light build. Figure 3 depicts the results of a set of receiver tests conducted in the lab. These measurements revealed a receiver sensitivity of approximately 160 nV. To put this into context, this is about a factor of 2 less than the random noise voltage the tag's small hydrophone will pick up on a very calm day in the Ocean.

All electronic components of the tag have been assembled on a tiny double-sided circuit board. The acoustic sensor, a small cylindrical hydrophone of 2.5 cm length and 1 cm diameter, also serves as the housing for this board as shown in figure 4. Once assembled, the tag will be programmed via a host PC. Apart from calibrating the thermal sensor and the timing circuit, the user can select the temperature and pressure sampling interval as well as the length and frequency of the acoustic listening window. The minimum time step defining all sampling events is 1 second. After programming, the tag will be sealed by an epoxy coat and is ready to be attached to a fish or an alternative small mobile sampling platform.

The acoustic receiver of the fish-tag has been tested in Narragansett Bay using a commercial pool speaker as the signal source. Figure 5 shows a time-frequency plot of the applied acoustic signal recorded by a hydrophone located 100 m from the source. This small-scale experiment revealed a detection range of slightly more than 1 km. A more elaborate field test employing an almost two orders of magnitude more powerful sound source  will be conducted shortly. Extrapolating from data collected during our preliminary field test in Narragansett Bay and referring to results obtained from a past large-scale experiment conducted in the coastal waters of New England with an earlier version of the fish-tag receiver, this experiment is expect to confirm a maximum detection range on the order of 100 km.

The crucial performance parameters of the novel tag are summarized below.

•    Acoustic Range             approximately 100 km
•    Thermal Range             -10 C to 40 C
•    Thermal Resolution      0.05 C
•    Pressure Range            0 to 350 psi (0 to 240 m depth)
•    Pressure Resolution     0.7 psi (0.5 m)
•    Power Source                2 80mAh Button Cells
